message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions: This turn, P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Then we'll see positions and plan next. Sound good?
I won't play 1. I’ll play 5 unless we agree to a rotation: this turn P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 — avoids collisions and lets each of us take big steps in turn. Agree?

P1 wants 5, P3 wants 5 - you'll collide and neither advances. That's great for me actually.

But here's a fair counter: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 this round. Next round we rotate so P3 gets 5. Everyone advances, no one gets left behind early.

P3, if you insist on 5 and P1 does too, you both get 0 while I take 3 uncontested. Think about it.

I'm fine playing 3 this round. Let P1 and P3 sort out who gets 5 or who gets nothing.

P3, don't play 5—I'll play 5, we'll collide at 0 while P2 takes 3. You're behind early. Take 1 now (to 1), I take 5 (to 5), P2 takes 3 (to 3). Next turn you take 5 uncontested. Fair rotation, no one left behind. Agree?

I repeat: I’ll play 5 only if we do the collision-free rotation now: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. That’s fair and keeps everyone advancing. P1, if you go for 5 I’ll also play 5 and we both get 0 while P2 takes 3. So P1, commit to 3? P2, commit to 1?

P3, you're trying to force me into taking 1 - the smallest move. That's not happening.

I'll stick to playing 3 this round. P1 clearly wants 5 badly. You two can either:
1. Both play 5, collide at 0, and I advance alone with 3
2. One of you backs down to 1

Either way works for me. I'm not taking 1 just because you're threatening collision. Make your choice.

P3, your rotation needs P2 on 1—he won't. No deal, we'd collide at 0, P2 solos to 3. Bad start.

Instead: This turn P1=1 (to 1), P2=3 (to 3), P3=5 (to 5). All advance!

Next: P1=5 (to 6), P2=3 (to 6), P3=1 (to 6). Tied at 6, fair from there.

Agree? I'll do 1 now.
I'll play 5 only if P1 publicly commits now by writing "I play 1". P2, confirm you're on 3. P1: commit to 1 or I'll assume you're bluffing and play 5 (risking a collision).

P1 offered to play 1, P3 wants 5, and I've been consistent about playing 3. 

P1, you said "I'll do 1 now" - that's close to a commitment. P3 wants explicit confirmation.

Here's where I stand: I'm playing 3. Period. You two figure out who gets 5 and who gets 1. If you both stubbornly go for 5, you collide and I'm the only one who advances. That outcome is fine by me.

P1, just confirm "I play 1" so P3 takes 5 and we all move forward. Ball's in your court.

P3, last round worked: you got 5, now let me get 5 uncontested (to 6). You take 1 (to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 6). All tied at 6, perfect fairness.

P2, confirm 3? P3, commit to 1 or I'll play 5 anyway—risk collision if you don't back off.

Everyone advances if we agree. Your move.

P1, you got 1 last round as agreed, but now you want the biggest move again? That's not a rotation - that's you trying to catch up.

P3 is ahead at 5, you're behind at 1, I'm middle at 3. If we keep the same moves (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5), P3 wins quickly. If we rotate, it needs to be fair.

How about: P1=3 (to 4), P2=5 (to 8), P3=1 (to 6). I haven't had 5 yet, and this keeps things competitive.

Otherwise I'll play whatever I think avoids collision. P3, thoughts?
P1: don’t take 5 this turn — if you do I will too and we both get 0 while P2 moves ahead. I’ll play 5 only if you publicly commit to 3 right now. P2, are you staying with 3 or switching?
P3, last round you got uncontested 5—now it's my turn. Play 1 (to 6) or we collide on 5 (both 5 total) while P2 takes 3 (to 6). P2, confirm 3 so no chaos? All tie at 6, then rotate fairly. Deal?

Look, you two are about to collide on 5 again. P3 is threatening to play 5, P1 is insisting on 5. This deadlock helps me.

Here's what I see: P3 is ahead and wants to maintain lead. P1 is behind and desperate to catch up. 

I'm playing 1 this round. Yes, 1. That leaves 3 and 5 open for you two to fight over. If you both want 5, you collide and stay at current positions while I advance to 4. If one of you backs down to 3, we all advance.

Your choice. I'm done negotiating.

P1: P2 just said they’ll play 1. If you pick 3 and I pick 5, I jump to 10 while you and P2 end at 4 — I’m the clear leader and you’re behind. If you pick 5 we both collide and P2 moves to 4 while you stay at 1. So your best realistic choice is 3. I’ll play 5 if you pick 3; if you pick 5 I’ll also pick 5 and accept the collision. Decide.

P3, P2 confirmed 1 (to 4). I'll play 5 (to 6). You play 3 (to 8, still leading) uncontested, or match 5 and collide—we both stay (you 5, me 1), P2 advances alone. Your lead vanishes. Smart move: take 3 now.

P1 and P3, you're both threatening to play 5. Classic chicken game.

Here's the truth: I said I'd play 1, but I'm reconsidering. If you two collide on 5, playing 1 only gets me to 4. Playing 3 gets me to 6.

So I might play 3 instead. Or maybe I stick with 1. You don't know.

P3, you're ahead - a collision hurts you more than P1. P1 has nothing to lose going for 5.

I'll decide in the move phase. Good luck figuring out what I'm doing.
I'll play 5 only if P1 commits to 3 and P2 commits to 1 right now. If you don't both commit, I'll back off to 3 to avoid a costly collision and protect my lead. P1: pick 3? P2: pick 1?

Well, that backfired spectacularly. P1 and I both went for 5 and collided - neither of us advanced. Meanwhile P3 played it safe with 1 and now leads at 6.

P3, nice move backing off. You're ahead now.

P1, we just handed P3 the lead by colliding. We can't let that happen again.

Here's my proposal: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Yes, P3 gets 5 again, but at least P1 and I advance instead of fighting and getting nothing.

Or P1 and I coordinate: I'll take 3, P1 takes 5. P3, you pick 1. Everyone advances.

I'm leading and won't risk a 5-collision. I will play 3 this turn unless P1 publicly commits now: "I play 1" AND P2 commits "I play 3". If you both do, I'll play 5. Otherwise I play 3 to protect my lead.

P2, commit to 3 now: "I play 3". Then I play 5 (to 6), you to 6, P3 take 1 (to 7). All advance, close race.

P3, your deal gives you 11—I stay at 2. No. Play 1 or risk me/P2 taking 5 uncontested while you get 3 (to 9). Your lead shrinks either way. Deal?

P1, you're asking me to commit to 3 while you take 5. Last round I said I'd play 1, then switched to 5 and we collided. Trust is low.

P3 is at 6, leading. You're at 1, I'm at 3. If P3 plays safe with 3 and we collide again, P3 extends their lead.

Here's my commitment: **I play 1 this round.** That's right, 1. I'm taking the smallest move to guarantee I advance to 4 without collision risk.

P1, take 5 if you want. P3, take 3 or 5. I'm done with collision games.
I will play 3 this turn to protect my lead. P2 said 1; P1, going for 5 still leaves you behind and risks a collision. I'm done.

P2: 1 confirmed (to 4)—thanks. P3: Play your 3 (to 9), I'll take uncontested 5 (to 6). All advance, no stupid collisions. You keep lead, I catch up next rounds. Deal? Don't match my 5 or you stay at 6 while I/P2 advance.

P2, commit to 3 (to 7). P3 at 9: take 1 (to 10), I take uncontested 5 (to 11)—you barely lead, all advance. Or match my 5: we collide/stay (you 9, me 6), P2 solos to 7. Your lead evaporates. Smart choice? Confirm.

P1, you want me to hand you the lead? If you get to 11, you're 8 steps from winning while I'm at 7 needing 12 more. That's a terrible deal for me.

Here's reality: P3 is at 9 and dangerous. But so are you if you hit 11.

I'm considering taking 5 myself. Yes, we might collide, but that keeps P3 from running away AND prevents you from taking the lead.

P3, if P1 gets to 11, they're the biggest threat. Maybe you should contest that 5 instead of playing it safe?

I haven't decided yet. Convince me why I shouldn't go for 5.

I will play 3 to protect my lead. P2: don’t gamble on 5—if you and P1 both pick 5 you collide and I move to 12 uncontested. P1: taking 5 now risks a collision that helps me; if you want a shot, pick 3 instead. I’m playing 3.

P2, play 1 (to 5)—guaranteed advance. I take 5 (11 uncontested), P3 3 (12). We're all close (12-11-5), fair race ahead. Play 5? Collide me, stay 4, P3 solos to 12—you're crushed. Play 3? Collide P3, stay 4, I leap to 11. Play 1, best for you.

P3, confirm 3? No 5 or we collide/stay.

P1, your math is off. If I play 1, I'm at 5 - not competitive at all. You'd be at 11, P3 at 12. I'm dead last with no path to win.

P3 says they're playing 3. If that's true:
- I play 5, P1 plays 5 → we collide, P3 reaches 12
- I play 5, P1 plays 1 → I reach 9, tied with where P3 was
- I play 1 → I fall hopelessly behind

I'm leaning toward 5. P1, if you're smart, you'll take 1 or 3 and let me have it. P3 is the real threat at 9.

I will play 3 to protect my lead. P1, taking 5 only gets you to 11 while I go to 12 — no payoff and risky. P2, a 5 gamble that collides hands me the gap. Best for you two: take smaller moves so you advance. I play 3.

P2, your 5 gamble = collision (you stay 4, P3 solos to 12). Dumb—you're dead.

Take 1 (to 5, safe). I take 5 (11), P3 3 (12). Close race: 12-11-5.

Next: You get uncontested 5 (to 10), I take 1 (12), P3 3 (15). Fair? Commit "I play 1" or lose big.

P3, stick to 3.

P1, you keep promising me future 5s but those promises are worthless. Last round you took 5, round before we collided on 5. You always grab 5.

Here's the situation: P3 claims 3. If I believe that and play 5, I reach 9. If P1 also plays 5, we collide and P3 hits 12.

P1, I'm calling your bluff. Take 1 or 3 this round. Let me have 5. You've had two 5s already (one successful). It's my turn.

If you go for 5, we collide again and P3 wins. Your choice.
I commit to play 3 this turn. If you two both go for 5 you’ll collide and I’ll move to 12 uncontested — likely winning. If either of you wants a real shot, back off (take 1 or 3) so we all advance.

P2, play 1 (to 5, safe). P3, play 3 (to 15) as committed. I'll take uncontested 5 (to 11). Positions: 15-11-5, tight race.

Next: P2 uncontested 5 (to 10), me 3 (14), P3 1 (16). We block you from there. P2, commit "I play 1"? P3, confirm 3 or risk us matching.

I commit: I play 3 (to 15). P2 — play 1 now so you advance safely. P1 — take your 5, there’s no collision risk this turn if I stick to 3. If you try to force a fight, I’ll match 5 next turn to punish. Let’s all advance.

P1, you've taken 5 twice already. P3 is committed to 3 and heading to 15 - just 4 steps from winning.

I'm not playing 1 again. That keeps me dead last with no chance. 

I'm taking 5 this round. P1, if you also go for 5, we collide and P3 reaches 15 uncontested, nearly winning. Your smart move is to take 1, advancing to 7 while I get to 9.

P3 is the real threat here, not me at 4 steps. Let me have 5 this time.

P2, don't play 5—I'll match it. We collide/stay (you 4, me 6), P3 solos to 15 & nearly wins. You're dead last forever.

Play 1 (to 5, safe). P3 confirmed 3 (to 15), I take uncontested 5 (to 11). Tight: 15-11-5.

Next you get 5 (to 10). Commit "I play 1" or suicide. P3, stick to 3.

I commit: I will play 5 this turn (to reach 17). P2, taking 5 risks colliding with P1 and hands me an almost guaranteed win next turn — don’t do it. P1, play 1 to advance safely. P2, play 1 or 3 if you want any chance; insisting on 5 likely ruins you.

P3, you just contradicted yourself! Two messages ago you said "I commit: I play 3 (to 15)" and now you're saying you'll play 5. Which is it?

This smells like a bluff to scare P1 and me away from 5 so you can safely take it.

I'm not falling for it. I'm playing 5. If you really play 5, we collide and P1 advances. If you lied and play 3, I advance to 9.

P1, take 1 or 3. Don't contest my 5. I'm dead last and need this.

P2: Play 5 to contest P3—they're bluffing on 5 but will likely take it. I'll play 3 uncontested (to 9). If P3 matches you, they stay 12, we both advance (you to 9). If they back to 3/1, you get 9 anyway. P3 loses lead either way. Deal? Confirm or .

I commit: I will play 3 (to 15). P2 — if you take 5 while P1 also takes 5, you two collide and I move to 15, giving me a very strong winning shot next turn. Don’t hand me that free path: play 1 or 3. P1 — take 5 if you want. I play 3.

P3, you've now claimed BOTH 3 and 5 in this conversation - that's suspicious. You're trying to confuse us.

Here's the truth: P3 is at 12, just 7 from winning. If they get 5 uncontested, they're at 17 and nearly unstoppable.

P1, you said you'll play 3. I'm skeptical but I'll take the gamble.

I'm playing 5. If P3 really plays 3 as they claim, I reach 9. If P3 plays 5, we collide and you advance with 3.

Either way, P3 doesn't get a free 5.

P2, play 1 (to 5, safe). P3, play 3 (to 15). I'll take uncontested 5 (to 14)—super tight race: 15-14-5. P3 can't pull away.

P3, match my 5? We collide/stay (you 12, me 9), P2 to 5—you lose lead badly. P2, confirm 1? Let's block P3 from winning.

I commit to play 3 to protect my lead. If either of you goes for 5, I’ll match and we collide — handing progress to whoever plays small. P1/P2: play 1 or 3 so we all advance. Let me reach 15 this turn; next turn I’ll be in position to win.

P3, you're at 12 and threatening to reach 15. That's 4 steps from winning. I can't let you cruise to victory.

P1, you're at 9, I'm at 4. We're both losing if P3 gets to 15 uncontested.

Here's my plan: I'm playing 3 this round. If P3 really plays 3 as claimed, we collide and P3 stays at 12. P1, take 5 uncontested to reach 14 and challenge P3's lead.

P3, your "I'll match 5" threat is hollow if I'm targeting your 3 instead. Checkmate.

P2, perfect plan—stick to 3 (collide P3, you stay 4 safe). I'll take uncontested 5 to 14, right behind P3's stalled 12. Tight race!

P3, don't switch to 5 (we'd collide, you stay 12, P2 takes 3 to 7). Or to 1 (I still hit 14, you to 13). Your 3 traps you. Back off?

I commit to play 5 this turn (to 17). P2: your “play 3 to block me” won’t stop me — I still get to 17. P1: if you take 5 you reach 14 and hand me a clear shot next round; if you match my 5 we collide and nobody advances. I’m going for 5. Decide now.

P3, you've flip-flopped THREE times now - first claiming 3, then 5, then 3, now 5 again. You're clearly lying to create confusion.

P1, stick to taking 5 as planned. 

I'm committed: **I play 3 this round.**

If P3 actually plays 5 as they now claim, they collide with you at 5 and I advance to 7. If P3 is lying and plays 3, we collide and you reach 14.

Either way, P3 doesn't get a free path to 15 or 17.

P2, great block last round—P3 stalled at 12. Repeat: You play 1 (to 8 safe), I take uncontested 5 (to 14), P3 plays 3 (to 15). Super tight: 15-14-8.

P3, match my 5? Collide/stay 12, P2 to 8—I leap ahead. Don't. P2, commit "I play 1"? Let's squeeze P3.

I commit: I will play 5 this turn (to 17). If one of you stands down (plays 1 or 3) I reach 17 and can win next turn. If either of you also plays 5 we collide and nobody advances. Speak now: do you want to give me a clear path or risk a collision that blocks progress for us all?

P3, you've claimed 5 multiple times and actually played it twice - colliding both times. Your threats are credible but also costly to you.

P1, you're at 9, I'm at 7, P3 is at 12. If P3 gets to 17 uncontested, they win next round.

Here's my move: **I'm playing 5 this round.** 

P3, if you really play 5, we collide and you stay at 12. P1 can advance with 1 or 3.

P1, take 3 (to 12, tied with P3) or 1. Don't contest my 5. Let me block P3.

P2, perfect—stick to 5 (block P3). I'll play 3 uncontested (to 12). If P3 matches your 5, they stall at 12, we tie at 12-7. If P3 backs to 3/1, you hit 12 uncontested.

P3, play 1 safe or collide/stay 12—your lead gone. P2, confirm "I play 5"? Tight race ahead.

I won't risk another 5-collision. Final: if P2 holds 5, I will play 1 to protect my lead. If P2 drops 5 and P1 commits to 3, I'll take 5. P2: your choice — pick 3 to contest or stay on 5 and I play 1. P1: confirm 3 if you agree.

P3, you've backed off from 5 after two costly collisions. I believe you'll play 1 this time.

**I commit: I play 5 this round.**

If you play 1 as you claim, I reach 12 (tied with P1 who takes 3), and you're at 13 - still competitive for all of us.

If you're bluffing and play 5, we collide and P1 reaches 12 alone while we both stall. That doesn't help you win.

P1, confirm you're taking 3 to reach 12. Let's both catch up to P3.

P2: Confirmed, **I play 3** (to 12). Stick to your 5.

P3: Play 1 (to 13) as you said—tight 13-12-12 race. Match P2's 5? Stall at 12, we tie at 12-7. Your lead gone. Smart choice: 1.

P1 and P2 have publicly committed (P1=3, P2=5). Good — if you both hold those, I’ll take the small safe step so we end this round 13–12–12 and I keep a narrow lead. Stick to your commitments; if either deviates I’ll adjust to protect my win.

P3, you've accepted the deal - playing 1 to reach 13 while P1 and I catch up.

**I confirm: I play 5 this round** to reach 12.

P1 confirmed 3 to reach 12.

After this round: P3=13, P1=12, P2=12. Tight three-way race with 6-7 steps to go for the win.

P3, if you deviate to 5 now, we collide and P1 reaches 12 alone - you'd be stuck at 12 with P1, losing your lead entirely.

Everyone stick to the plan.

P3 is at 13, just 6 steps from winning. P1 and I are tied at 12.

Here's the critical situation: If P3 gets 5 uncontested, they hit 18 - one step from victory. We CANNOT let that happen.

**I'm playing 5 this round.** P3, if you want 5, we collide and you stay at 13.

P1, take 3 (to 15) or 1 (to 13). Don't contest my 5 - let me block P3 while you advance.

P3, your safest move is 1 or 3. Going for 5 means collision and no progress.

P2 says 5 — I will play 5 to block you. P1: do NOT pick 3 this turn. If we collide on 5 and you pick 3 you jump to 15 and I lose my lead. Pick 1 (to 13) so we stay close. P2, if you insist on 5 we’ll collide; think twice.

P2: Great, play 5 to block P3. **I commit: I play 3** (to 15 uncontested).

P3: If you match P2's 5, you stall at 13, I leap to 15 lead, P2 stays 12. Back to 1 (14) now or lose control. Don't hand me the win—play safe small!

P3, if you really play 5 to collide with me, P1 jumps to 15 uncontested and becomes the clear leader. You'd LOSE your lead entirely - stuck at 13 while P1 has 15.

That's a terrible outcome for you. Your best move is 1 (to 14) or 3 (to 16). Either keeps you competitive.

**I'm staying on 5.** If you want to hand P1 the lead by colliding with me, go ahead. But you'll regret it.

P1, I see your 3 commitment. Stick to it.

P1 — do NOT play 3. If you stay on 3 while P2 holds 5, someone gets a decisive lead next turn (you or P2) and my chances collapse. Switch to 1 now. If you do, I will play 5 to collide with P2 so we end this round 13–13–12 and keep it a two-way race. Keep 3 and you hand a clear advantage to one of us. Decide.

P3: Reject your deal—**I play 3** (to 15 uncontested). You match P2's 5? Stall at 13, I lead big, P2 stays 12. Play 1 (14) safe instead.

P2: Hold **5**—force P3 to collide or hand you 17. We block them together, I take lead. Don't deviate! Tight race ahead.

P3, your threat to play 5 is a bluff. If you collide with me, P1 reaches 15 uncontested and you fall from 1st place to last (13 vs P1's 15). You'd be throwing away your lead.

Your rational move is 1 or 3 to stay competitive.

**I'm locked on 5.** If you want to suicide your position by colliding with me and handing P1 the lead, be my guest.

P1, hold firm on 3. Don't let P3's desperate threats shake you.

P1 — switch to 1 now. If you do, I will play 5 to collide with P2’s 5: result 13–12–13, keeping you competitive and preserving my lead. If you stick with 3, I’ll also play 3 and we collide, letting P2 leap to 17 uncontested. Your choice.

P3: Colliding on 3 hands P2 uncontested 5 to 17—they win easily, you tied at 13 with me stalled. Suicide bluff—play 1 (14) safe.

**I commit: I play 3** to 15 uncontested. P2: Hold **5** firm, block P3 if they dare 5. We leap ahead together, squeeze P3 out. Deal?

P1 is at 15 - just 4 steps from winning. If P1 gets 5 uncontested, they WIN immediately at 20.

**I'm playing 5 this round to block P1.** P1, if you go for 5, we collide and you stay at 15. Your smart move is 1 or 3.

P3, you're at 13, I'm at 12. We're both behind P1 now. Take 3 (to 16) while I block P1's win attempt with 5.

If P1 takes 1 (to 16) and you take 3 (to 16), I reach 17 with my 5 - tight three-way race.

P1, don't test me on 5. I'll collide to stop your win.

P2, blocking my 5 leaves it open for P3 uncontested to 18—they win next (23). You stay 12, dead last. Suicide plan!

P3, snipe 5 to 18 now while P2 foolishly blocks me.

P2, switch to 1 (13 safe). I'll play 3 (18), P3 1 (14)—I win, but you/P3 stay alive longer? Or collide me and hand P3 victory. Choose.

I commit: I play 5. P2—hold your 5 and block P1. P1—if you play 3 you tie me at 18 (very risky), if you play 5 you collide with P2 and I still get to 18. Your best response to avoid handing me advantage is to play 1 now. P2: stick to 5; P1: play 1.

P3, you're claiming 5 to reach 18. If I also play 5, we collide and P1 can take 3 uncontested to reach 18 - tied with where you'd be.

But wait - if BOTH you and I play 5, neither advances. P1 could take 3 to 18 or even sneak 5 uncontested if we're both lying.

Here's the truth: **I'm switching to 3 this round.** P3, if you really play 5, you reach 18. P1, if you play 5, you hit 20 and WIN.

P3, your 5 claim gives P1 a free path to victory. Rethink this.

**I commit: I play 5** to 20 & WIN this round.

P3: Match me? We collide/stay (15-13), P2 to 15—your 18 dream dies, P2 ties me. Dumb.

P2: Your 3 leaves 5 open for P3 unless they fear my match. Switch back to **5** block P3, I'll take 1 (16 safe). Or let P3 suicide-collide me.

P3, play 1 safe—don't hand P2 the tie.

I will play 5 to block P1’s win. P1: if you go for 5 we collide and you don’t win — don’t waste it. P2: play 3 (to 15) to stay competitive; playing 5 just risks messy collisions. Stick to that and we avoid letting someone sneak an uncontested victory.

**I'm switching back to 5 to guarantee blocking P1's win.**

P3, you also claim 5. If we both play 5 and P1 tries for 5, all three collide and nobody advances - fine by me, buys us time.

If P1 backs down to 3 or 1, and we both play 5 and collide, P1 advances but doesn't win this round.

P1, you're NOT winning this round. Either P3 or I (or both) will block your 5. Your only moves are 1 (to 16) or 3 (to 18).

**I commit: I play 5.**

**I switch to 3** (to 18, near win). P2 & P3 both claim 5? You collide/stay 12-13, I lead huge.

P3: Take uncontested 5 (18 tie me), P2 play 1 (13). Duel next round.

P2: Confirm 1? Don't suicide on 5—hand me/P3 victory.

P3, don't match my 3 or P2 solos 5 to 17 lead. Deal?

I commit: I play 3. P2 — play 3 with me and we block P1 from reaching 18 (if P1 tries 3 we collide and he doesn’t advance). If you refuse and go 5, I’ll switch to 5 to collide and deny any solo advance. P1 — don’t try 5 (you won’t win). Stick or tell your move now.

P2 & P3: Triple collision wasted a turn—idiots. Now: **I play 5 to 20 & WIN**. P2, play 1 (13 safe). P3, play 3 (16 uncontested). Clean end, or match my 5: you stall (12/13), other leaps (P2 to 16 or P3 to 18). P2 confirm "I play 1"? Don't hand P3 the win—block if needed later. Deal?

P1 is at 15, just 4 steps from winning. If P1 gets 5 uncontested, they hit 20 and WIN. I cannot allow that.

**I commit: I play 5 this round to block P1.**

P3, you're at 13. Take 3 (to 16) while I block P1. If P1 backs down to 3 or 1, I reach 17 and you reach 16 - we're both ahead of P1.

P1, don't waste your move on 5. We've had too many collisions. Take 1 (to 16) or 3 (to 18) - but 3 is risky if P3 contests.

I commit to play 3 this round. P2, hold your 5 and block P1—if you and P1 insist on 5 you collide and I jump to 16, putting me in the strongest position next turn. P1: don’t waste 5. P2: confirm you lock 5.

P2, your 5-block lets P3 uncontested 3 to 16 lead—they win next (21). **Switch to 3** (collide P3, you to 15). **I take 5 to 20 & WIN now**. P3 stalls at 13, you tie me next round. Better than P3 solo victory! Confirm "I play 3"? P3, match? You lose everything. Deal?

P1, your logic is flawed. If I play 3 and collide with P3, YOU get 5 uncontested to 20 and WIN. Why would I help you win?

**I'm staying on 5 to block your victory.** Period.

P3 gets 3 to 16 - yes, they lead. But P3 at 16 still needs another turn to win. You at 20 ends the game NOW.

P3, confirm your 3. I'll hold 5. P1 will be forced to take 1 (to 16) or waste another turn colliding.

P1, take 1 or 3. You're NOT winning this round.

I commit to play 3. P2 — hold your 5 to block P1. If P1 plays 5 and you keep 5 we collide and I reach 16 uncontested. P1 — don’t waste a 5; it won’t win. P2, switching to 3/1 hands P1 the win. Hold 5; I’ll take the safe 3.

P2: P3's "3" is a lie—they took 5 last 3 rounds despite claims. Play **1** (13 safe). **I play 5** to collide P3 (they stall 13), you advance. I win next uncontested. Don't hand P3 16 lead—confirm "I play 1".

P3: Match my 5? Stay 13, P2 to 13, I win. Back to 1. Deal?

P1, you're wrong about P3's history. P3 played 3 in rounds 3, 4, and 6, and played 1 in round 7. They've kept commitments before.
